content.raw: please remove the apt cache to avoid storing it in every layer of the image (this makes images pretty big at the end of the day). We should remove the lists after each apt update call, example here: https://github.com/osrf/docker_images/blob/40903f632eca1bf5fef2c8420511b3ddc9c4409b/ros/kinetic/ubuntu/xenial/desktop/Dockerfile#L8

content.raw:
a nicer way to do this is to provide an entry point.

From docker docs: "If you would like your container to run the same executable every time, then you should consider using ENTRYPOINT in combination with CMD. See ENTRYPOINT."

Example here: https://github.com/osrf/docker_images/tree/master/ros/lunar/ubuntu/xenial/ros-core
content.html:
a nicer way to do this is to provide an entry point.

Example here: https://github.com/osrf/docker_images/tree/master/ros/lunar/ubuntu/xenial/ros-core

content.raw: Surprised that this works as we don't define ROS_DISTRO. I guess it's because this is using desktop as a base image. But if that's the case that means that `/opt/ros/kinetic/setub.bash` is already sourced so there is no need to resource it so we can remove the entrypoint completely
content.html: Surprised that this works as we don't define ROS_DISTRO. I guess it's because this is using desktop as a base image. But if that's the case that means that /opt/ros/kinetic/setub.bash is already sourced so there is no need to resource it so we can remove the entrypoint completely

pullrequest.title: Added Dockerfile, build and run bash files

content.raw:
Just tried it on a machine that never built it before and I didn't need to source the setup file to get it working.

I started from scratch and had to install nvidia-docker. The wik point to the nvidia-docker repo that makes you install nvidia-docker v2.  openGL currently doesn't work with v2 and the current ros docker images  so I cannot launch either RViz or Gazebo. The Docker instructions on the wiki should be updated to make users install nvidia-docker v1.
content.html:
Just tried it on a machine that never built it before and I didn't need to source the setup file to get it working.

I started from scratch and had to install nvidia-docker. The wik point to the nvidia-docker repo that makes you install nvidia-docker v2. openGL currently doesn't work with v2 and the current ros docker images so I cannot launch either RViz or Gazebo. The Docker instructions on the wiki should be updated to make users install nvidia-docker v1.

pullrequest.title: Added Dockerfile, build and run bash files

content.raw:
hmmm, that's surprising.
Does it work out-of-the-box if you rebuild the image from scratch after restoring the entry point ? If so you can revert #!/osrf/servicesim/commits/96bfa36133859892fbfc8fb95236355e7f0ce53d (just the entrypoint part, the other changes are unrelated) to force another sourcing at startup.

I'm unable to reproduce the issue and am very puzzled as I don't see why rviz would work and not servicesim as they are both installed in layers above the one sourcing the setup file o_O, so I don;t see why one would work and not the other... Can you please post the error message and/or any other useful information (ROS environment variables etc) for the day I may look into it more closely ?
content.html:
hmmm, that's surprising. Does it work out-of-the-box if you rebuild the image from scratch after restoring the entry point ? If so you can revert #!/osrf/servicesim/commits/96bfa36133859892fbfc8fb95236355e7f0ce53d (just the entrypoint part, the other changes are unrelated) to force another sourcing at startup.

I'm unable to reproduce the issue and am very puzzled as I don't see why rviz would work and not servicesim as they are both installed in layers above the one sourcing the setup file o_O, so I don;t see why one would work and not the other... Can you please post the error message and/or any other useful information (ROS environment variables etc) for the day I may look into it more closely ?

content.raw: The sourcing currently comes from [ros-core](https://github.com/osrf/docker_images/tree/master/ros/kinetic/ubuntu/xenial/ros-core). As all the other images (ros-base, ros-desktop etc) build on top of ros core they (didn't seem to) need to source the file again

pullrequest.title: Added Dockerfile, build and run bash files

content.raw:
If the only reason for installing terminator is to allow multiple terminals, I don't think it's justified, especially if we dont explain to users how to use it.
People can install tmux or whatever terminal management management tool they prefer. They can also just use `docker exec` to log in the container from another terminal.
content.html: If the only reason for installing terminator is to allow multiple terminals, I don't think it's justified, especially if we dont explain to users how to use it. People can install tmux or whatever terminal management management tool they prefer. They can also just use docker exec to log in the container from another terminal.

pullrequest.title: Added Dockerfile, build and run bash files

content.raw:
`BASH_SOURCE` is a bash variable so in this case the file should be a bash file and not sh.

Though as we tell people to be in the right directory I don't think that logic is required. replacing this entire file to be:
```
#! /usr/bin/env sh

docker build -t osrf/servicesim ./
```

is enough to get things working without error messages
content.html:
BASH_SOURCE is a bash variable so in this case the file should be a bash file and not sh.

Though as we tell people to be in the right directory I don't think that logic is required. replacing this entire file to be:

#! /usr/bin/env sh

docker build -t osrf/servicesim ./

is enough to get things working without error messages

pullrequest.title: Added Dockerfile, build and run bash files

content.raw:
I think it's a socket used by the 3d space nav controllers (libspnav).
In this particular case I don't think it's necessary as we don't plan on using such sensor in this project. My guess is that this has been copied from a dockerfile of another project that used such device.
content.html: I think it's a socket used by the 3d space nav controllers (libspnav). In this particular case I don't think it's necessary as we don't plan on using such sensor in this project. My guess is that this has been copied from a dockerfile of another project that used such device.

pullrequest.title: Added Dockerfile, build and run bash files

content.raw: Gazebo debs are distributed [with support](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo8-release/src/aedfd1a2d959d0542fd7c42f88f4bdd2ed8c2805/xenial/debian/control.orig?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#control.orig-41) for the SpaceNav 3D mouse, so I think it doesn't hurt to leave the socket open in case someone wants to use it, it can be quite convenient to navigate large environments such as ServceSim's
content.html: Gazebo debs are distributed with support for the SpaceNav 3D mouse, so I think it doesn't hurt to leave the socket open in case someone wants to use it, it can be quite convenient to navigate large environments such as ServceSim's
